body: This was a conscious decision. The extra config added unnecessary complexity, and we were never able to come up with a use case for the websockets being run on a different host from the rest of the server. The idea of two proxies pointing to one server definitely hadn't occurred to us (and seems super bizarre).  We can consider restoring the ws_host configurable.

I don't understand. The notebook server is one process that listens on a single port for both HTTP and WebSocket traffic. The reason we got rid of the configurability is that if you set the WebSocket port to something different than the HTTP port in the JavaScript frontend, you have to write a entirely custom notebook server that runs these services on different ports - something that our server has never done. I don't see how any proxy magic can change that unless you are also customizing the server itself in a non-trivial way. Can you clarify?

It's definitely possible that my use case is strange or I'm not handling it in the best way. Basically, I have an OpenShift app, which is is kind of like a VM, with an Apache web server listening on 80. Apache routes 80 to 8080, where I have nginx listening. (I would have just put nginx on 80, but the global Apache is an OpenShift requirement).

Next, nginx is set as a reverse proxy to send /ipython/ requests to the ipython backend and /cloud9/ requests to the cloud9 backend. Both IPython and Cloud9 use websockets, so I don't believe I can run both on port 8000. (Is this correct??) Cloud9 has a config parameter that allows one to set the port it uses for web socket connections (but not the full host url). For IPython, I had to modify the source code as mentioned above. Everything works the way I have it set up, but it's not good to hack the source. Here's a chat log from someone in the past who had a similar [problem](http://logs.nodejs.org/openshift/2013-03-26) (search for user `zemanel`).

It seems like the crux of the issue is that **OpenShift only supports websockets on specific ports**.

Here is my interpretation of your setup:

Internet ----> Apache (80) ----> nginx (8080) ----> /ipython/ ----> ipython
(8000)

 ----> /cloud9/ ----> cloud9 (????)

Questions:
- Are the ipython server and cloud9 servers running on the same machine?
- What ports are the ipython server and cloud9 server listening on?
- When you say that "*OpenShift only supports websockets on specific ports"
  *which of these links does that refer to?
- Can you show us your nginx proxy config?
- What port did you change the WebSocket port to in the JavaScript code? I
  would guess this has to be 80 as that is the only public port for the
  apache server?

I think I am starting to understand the issue though. Basically, the
IPython web server listens for web socket on one port p1=8000, but the
apache proxy in front listens on port port2=80. The JavaScript code needs
to make its WebSocket connections on port 80. One way of fixing this is to
use the same port number everywhere (port1=port2), but OpenShift prevents
this by only supporting WebSockets on port 8080. Is this a good summary?

@minrk if this is right, then this will definitely affect our multiuser
server as the single user notebook servers will be using some random high
port, but the main proxy will be using something like 80/443.

Cheers,

Brian

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

@ellisonbg: Thanks for looking into this! Let me clarify a bit better:

The diagram is close to what you drew, but the port for the ipython server is not 8000. In my case it's 5001, but that's just a random choice. It's the same with cloud9:
Internet ----> Apache (80) ----> nginx (8080) ----> /ipython/ ----> ipython (5001)
Internet ----> Apache (80) ----> nginx (8080) ----> /cloud9/ ----> cloud9 (3131)

Also, here are some answers to your questions:

> - Are the ipython server and cloud9 servers running on the same machine?

Yes

> - What ports are the ipython server and cloud9 server listening on?

5001 and 3131, respectively, although this choice is arbitrary

> - When you say that "*OpenShift only supports websockets on specific ports" which of these links does that refer to?

[Here's](https://www.openshift.com/blogs/paas-websockets) a good explanation

> - Can you show us your nginx proxy config?

Here's the relevant IPython part:

```
upstream ipython_server {
    server <%= ENV['OPENSHIFT_DIY_IP'] %>:5001;
}
...
server{
    ...
    location /ipython {
        proxy_pass http://ipython_server;

        # Needed for the websockets connections:
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";

        # Host and Origin in the request header don't seem to get passed
        # correctly by nginx. Host gets passed as http://ipython_server
        # and Origin is blank. This is just a hack, which really shouldn't
        # be this way:
        proxy_set_header Host <%= ENV['OPENSHIFT_DIY_IP'] %>:8000;
        proxy_set_header Origin http://<%= ENV['OPENSHIFT_DIY_IP'] %>:8000;
    }
    ...
}
```

> - What port did you change the WebSocket port to in the JavaScript code? I
>   would guess this has to be 80 as that is the only public port for the
>   apache server?

I changed the web sockets to use port 8000. This port is open on the machine and I don't think it's handled by the Apache server. (I could be wrong about the latter, though.)

> I think I am starting to understand the issue though. Basically, the
> IPython web server listens for web socket on one port p1=8000, but the
> apache proxy in front listens on port port2=80. The JavaScript code needs
> to make its WebSocket connections on port 80. One way of fixing this is to
> use the same port number everywhere (port1=port2), but OpenShift prevents
> this by only supporting WebSockets on port 8080. Is this a good summary?

I think that this is basically correct if you change the port numbers around. The IPython server runs on an arbitrary port (5001 in my case). Nginx forwards incoming /ipython requests to the IPython server. When a new notebook is created, my hack to kernel.js (shown above) makes IPython upgrade to a web socket connection on port 8000. How exactly the web socket connection gets routed, I'm not entirely sure, but it seems to work just fine and plays well with Cloud9, which is also running web sockets on port 8000. (Note that Cloud9 has a configuration file where you can specify a web socket connection port.) I'm also able to run multiple notebooks simultaneously, so the web socket connections don't appear to "collide" so to speak. 

Thanks again for looking into this!
-Steve

Thanks this is helpful. A few more...
- Which server is listening on port 8000? Same server that runs apache?
- Is that server that is facing the public internet?
- Where does incoming traffic on that public server:8000 get redirected -
  to the nginx proxy?

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

- I actually don't have anything running on port 8000, which puzzles me. I don't really understand what happens with the web socket connection.
- I'm also not sure if the server is facing the public internet. It's behind a corporate firewall and I have to open a VPN connection to access the website.
- Traffic to port 8000 goes to the nginx proxy. When testing access to my homepage (located at root, /), adding port 8000 does nothing, but 8080 gets blocked and I don't know why.

OK, my interpretation is that OpenShift runs a WebSocket routing system on
port 8000 for all of its servers. Basically, it runs next to Apache on port
80 and handles all of the WS traffic for that server. The WebSocket routing
system forwards to the WS traffic to the backend, which for your ase in the
nginx server. Based on your descriptions, I think we do need to make this
configurable again.

@minrk do you agree with my assessment? How do you think we should design
this to work with the multiuser notebook server?

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

This seems like a really awful system. I don't think there's anything that would be different about the multiuser server from the single-user server, since as far as all of our server-side code is concerned, everything is running on one host (behind node-http-proxy). It's purely client-side config for setting this URL, and none of our code will ever make any use of it. So this is strictly adding config to support completely bizarre multi-hop proxy setups.  But it's still pretty easy, just adding the ws host back to the kernel model, and leaving it empty by default, so the current behavior would be completely unchanged.

Let's say that our multiuser server looks like this:

multiuser server proxy (443) ----> single user A (10001)
                                              ----> single user B (10002)
                                              ----> single user C (10003)

The JavaScript/WebSocket code in kernel.js for all three users needs to
point to port 443. Right now I don't think that is possible as the
WebSocket port will always match the main server port (10001, etc. for each
user). So don't we have to allow for this customization to get the
multiuser server to work? I want to make sure I am not missing something.

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
Based on this [link](http://support.run.pivotal.io/entries/49512163-Does-cloudfoundry-support-websocket-) it looks like CloudFoundary might also only support websockets on one port...
configurable websocket_url should be restored in #6036.

The config should be the same as before, but ws_url is not in the Kernel model, so kernels are not allowed to have different URLs (was technically supported in the REST API before, but never possible to actually accomplish). A single ws url per application server makes much more sense, and is a much smaller burden to the code as a whole.

That should do it. I'll check it later, but it looks fine to me.

Thanks!

Ahh, got it, yes, what you are describing is definitely sufficient, we
don't need different kernel locations, just one configurable for all of
them.

Is there some way I can change this from command line? I tried `--NotebookApp.websocket_url`, `--NotebookApp.ws_url`, `--websocket_url` and `--websocket_url` but its not working :(

`ipython notebook --NotebookApp.websocket_url='wss://foo.bar.com:7654'` works for me on master ( well connexion do not work, but I get the `Starting WebSockets: wss://foo.bar.com:7654/api/kernels/48c2e54e-392d-4ed0-a18d-764a02bb4f83` message in teh JS console.
Does not work for me. I installed using `pip install "ipython[notebook]"` (just now), maybe thats the reason? `ipython --version` says `2.3.1`.
Yes, this is only development version, you can see on the right sidebar that it says 3.0

Installed from git, getting `403` reponse from iPy now, I have no idea why. Log says:

```
[W 15:49:02.428 NotebookApp] Couldn't authenticate WebSocket connection
[W 15:49:02.430 NotebookApp] 403 GET /api/kernels/41f30668-8147-47dd-84f0-4e7b19b5e320/shell?session_id=4A64BD2B6516499ABDFE1AFF7813C941 (127.0.0.1) 4.98ms referer=None
```

What is your setup ? Do you have like a custom app ? 
It's hard to tell without more details, like how you launched...

The start script is like:

```
cd data
exec ../env/bin/ipython notebook \
                        --no-browser \
                        --port 65170 \
                        --ip=127.0.0.1 \
                        --NotebookApp.websocket_url="wss://ipy.example.com:65180" \
                        --ipython-dir="../profile" \
                        --NotebookApp.password="$HASH"
```

Directory structure:
- data (notebooks should be here later)
- env (virtualenv with ipython installed from git/master branch)
- profile (folder with ipy profile (default profile, no changes by me))

I connect with HTTPS on port 443 (Apache), reverse proxying to localhost:65170 (ipy), but,
Websockets should use HTTPS and port 65180 (nginx) because my Apache version doesnt support websockets,
the notebook itself runs on port 65170 (not accessible from outside).

Hum, ok, so you are actually just authenticating with the same server so there should not be any issues with sharing secret. let me have look at the code. 
The authentication cookie might take into account the domain port, so there might be some extra config to set up.
Ok, can you open an issue for that? I can't make it work either even on localhost without auth.
Sure: #7178
